For more than a week preparations were being made for Nicholas.
Rough drafts of letters to Nicholas were written by all the household.
Rough drafts of letters to Nicholas were copied out.
The countess supervised the preparations for Nicholas.
The count solicited the preparations for Nicholas.
Money was collected for the uniform and equipment of the newly commissioned officer Nicholas.
Anna Mikháylovna managed to secure advantageous means of communication for herself and Nicholas by favor with army authorities.
Anna Mikháylovna had opportunities of sending her letters to Grand Duke Constantine Pávlovich.
Grand Duke Constantine Pávlovich commanded the Guards.
The Rostóvs supposed that The Russian Guards, Abroad, was a definite address.
The Rostóvs supposed that if a letter reached Grand Duke Constantine Pávlovich it would reach the Pávlograd regiment.
The Pávlograd regiment was presumably somewhere in the same neighborhood as The Russian Guards, Abroad.
It was decided to send the letters and money by Grand Duke Constantine Pávlovich’s courier to Borís.
Borís was to forward the letters and money to Nicholas.
The letters were from the old count, the countess, Pétya, Véra, Natásha, and Sónya.
The letters included six thousand rubles for Nicholas’s outfit.
The letters included various other things the old count sent to Nicholas.
On the twelfth of November, Kutúzov’s active army was in camp before Olmütz.
Kutúzov’s active army was preparing to be reviewed next day by the two Emperors—the Russian and the Austrian.
The Guards just arrived from Russia.
The Guards spent the night ten miles from Olmütz.
The Guards next morning were to come straight to the review.
The Guards reached the field at Olmütz by ten o’clock.
